elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sectitle0010">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="abspara0010" view="all">Large cadmium chalcogenido clusters C2 (Cd<ce:inf loc="post">32</ce:inf>) and C1 (Cd<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>) CdQ (<ce:italic>Q</ce:italic> = S, Se) with photoactive dye cations [Ru(Phen/Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> are prepared under solvothermal conditions (Phen = 1,10-phenanthroline, Bpy = 2,2′-bipyridine). All the C2 compounds are 3-D polymeric structures, while the C1 compounds are discrete Cd17 clusters. Two of the 3-D C2 clusters can be considered as homosized nano CdSe@CdS core–shell particles (2.0 nm radius) with Cd<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Se<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf> core. Charge-transfer interaction is found between [Ru(Phen/Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cations and CdQ cluster anions. The photocurrent behaviors indicate that (1) the current intensities are greatly increased for the dye cation functionalized C<ce:italic>n</ce:italic> clusters, (2) the current intensities of the 3-D C2 clusters are larger than those of the discrete C1 clusters, and (3) the current intensities of the selenide clusters are larger than those of the sulfide clusters.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract
Large cadmium chalcogenido clusters C2 (Cd32) and C1 (Cd17) CdQ (Q = S, Se) with photoactive dye cations [Ru(Phen/Bpy)3]2+ are prepared under solvothermal conditions (Phen = 1,10-phenanthroline, Bpy = 2,2′-bipyridine). All the C2 compounds are 3-D polymeric structures, while the C1 compounds are discrete Cd17 clusters. Two of the 3-D C2 clusters can be considered as homosized nano CdSe@CdS core–shell particles (2.0 nm radius) with Cd4Se10 core. Charge-transfer interaction is found between [Ru(Phen/Bpy)3]2+ cations and CdQ cluster anions. The photocurrent behaviors indicate that (1) the current intensities are greatly increased for the dye cation functionalized Cn clusters, (2) the current intensities of the 3-D C2 clusters are larger than those of the discrete C1 clusters, and (3) the current intensities of the selenide clusters are larger than those of the sulfide clusters.

Large size cadmium chalcogenido clusters with ruthenium complex cations are prepared.
Cation–anion charge-transfer property is found for these chalcogenido materials.
The intensity of photocurrent is related to the cluster size and the chalcogenido elements of the clusters.
Introduction
Cadmium chalcogenido quantum dots have attracted much attention because of their intriguing and unique optoelectronic properties. Synthetic challenges in this field include controlling the size and size distribution of the nanoparticles and modifying structure . Large nanosized cadmium chalcogenido clusters have not only the definite structures, but also the extremely low limit of the size distribution and high stability. Therefore, a ‘bottom-up’ approach to the synthesis of well defined large cadmium chalcogenido clusters has been recognized as a key to developing the semiconductor quantum dots technologically . These clusters generally fall into three series: supertetrahedral clusters (Tn), pentasupertetrahedral clusters (Pn), and capped tetrahedral clusters (Cn) . The most exploited large size clusters CdQ (Q = S and Se) are the Cn clusters having 17 , 32 , and 54  cadmium atoms in the clusters (). Besides the potential applications as quantum dots, they could serve as model systems and provide synthetic and structural insights into the formation and properties of nanomaterials. The recent challenges in the CdQ clusters field include functionalizing the cluster materials with counterions or substituents having unique photo or electrochemical properties, such as metal 1,10-phenanthroline (Phen) complexes and methyl viologe .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0030" view="all">The Ru(II)-Phen/Bpy (Bpy = 2,2′-bipyridine) complexes are photochemical dye-sensitizers, which offers extensive applications in solar light harvesting and energy conversion . Recent researches have indicated that some new charge-transfer systems based on both M-Phen/Bpy complex dyes and CdQ quantum dots have promising applications in sensitized solar cells and photoluminescent sensors . Such solar cells can not only overcome the photocorrosion of CdQ quantum dots, but also, especially, improve the charge separation and the efficient hole transfer from CdQ to dye, which eliminates the exciton annihilation process and allows a leisurely electron injection into semiconductor substrate, giving a high incident photon-to-current conversion efficiency . Therefore, subsequent interest has been attracted for us in studying the CdQ-M-Phen/Bpy systems. Although a C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-CdS cluster with [Ru(Phen)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cation was prepared and characterized crystallographically, the electrochemical and photoelectrochemical properties have not been studied .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The Ru(II)-Phen/Bpy (Bpy = 2,2′-bipyridine) complexes are photochemical dye-sensitizers, which offers extensive applications in solar light harvesting and energy conversion . Recent researches have indicated that some new charge-transfer systems based on both M-Phen/Bpy complex dyes and CdQ quantum dots have promising applications in sensitized solar cells and photoluminescent sensors . Such solar cells can not only overcome the photocorrosion of CdQ quantum dots, but also, especially, improve the charge separation and the efficient hole transfer from CdQ to dye, which eliminates the exciton annihilation process and allows a leisurely electron injection into semiconductor substrate, giving a high incident photon-to-current conversion efficiency . Therefore, subsequent interest has been attracted for us in studying the CdQ-M-Phen/Bpy systems. Although a C2-CdS cluster with [Ru(Phen)3]2+ cation was prepared and characterized crystallographically, the electrochemical and photoelectrochemical properties have not been studied .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0035" view="all">We have been interested in chalcogenides with metal-Phen/Bpy complex cations . Charge-transfer and fluorescent properties of the Ru-Phen functionalized CdS clusters were studied . Herein the synthesis of six C1 (Cd<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>) and C2 (Cd<ce:inf loc="post">32</ce:inf>) CdQ (<ce:italic>Q</ce:italic> = S, Se) clusters with [Ru(Phen/Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> dyes are reported. Charge-transfer property of these materials is discussed. Effective photocurrent responsive properties are found for these charge-transfer materials, which are related to the cluster size and the chalcogenido elements (S or Se) of the clusters. The cation–anion cooperative mechanism is discussed.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: We have been interested in chalcogenides with metal-Phen/Bpy complex cations . Charge-transfer and fluorescent properties of the Ru-Phen functionalized CdS clusters were studied . Herein the synthesis of six C1 (Cd17) and C2 (Cd32) CdQ (Q = S, Se) clusters with [Ru(Phen/Bpy)3]2+ dyes are reported. Charge-transfer property of these materials is discussed. Effective photocurrent responsive properties are found for these charge-transfer materials, which are related to the cluster size and the chalcogenido elements (S or Se) of the clusters. The cation–anion cooperative mechanism is discussed.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sectitle0035">Experimental section</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sectitle0040">General remarks</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">All analytically pure starting materials were purchased and used without additional purification. [Me<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>N]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>[Cd<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>Se<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(SPh)<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>] cluster, [Ru(Phen/Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]Br<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, and Cd(SPh)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> were prepared by the reported methods . Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were performed using a VARIDEL III elemental analyzer. FT-IR spectra were recorded with a Nicolet Magna-IR 550 spectrometer in dry KBr pellets. Room-temperature optical diffuse reflectance spectra of the micro crystal samples were obtained with a Shimadzu UV-3150 spectrometer. Data of X-ray diffraction were collected on a D/MAX-3C diffractometer using a Cu tube source (Cu-κ<ce:italic>α</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>λ</ce:italic> = 1.5406 Å). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained using a Tecnai G220 instrument. The electrospray mass spectra were recorded on Finnigan LCQ electrospray spectrometer.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental section
General remarks
All analytically pure starting materials were purchased and used without additional purification. [Me4N]2[Cd17Se4(SPh)26] cluster, [Ru(Phen/Bpy)3]Br2, and Cd(SPh)2 were prepared by the reported methods . Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were performed using a VARIDEL III elemental analyzer. FT-IR spectra were recorded with a Nicolet Magna-IR 550 spectrometer in dry KBr pellets. Room-temperature optical diffuse reflectance spectra of the micro crystal samples were obtained with a Shimadzu UV-3150 spectrometer. Data of X-ray diffraction were collected on a D/MAX-3C diffractometer using a Cu tube source (Cu-κα, λ = 1.5406 Å). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained using a Tecnai G220 instrument. The electrospray mass spectra were recorded on Finnigan LCQ electrospray spectrometer.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sectitle0045">Synthesis</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sectitle0050">C2-CdSSeRuBpy (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">[Ru(Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>][Cd<ce:inf loc="post">32</ce:inf>Se<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf>(SPh)<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>]. The precursor Cd(SPh)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (3.0 mg, 0.010 mmol), selenourea (1.0 mg, 0.008 mmol), and Ru(Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (1.0 mg, 0.0013 mmol) were mixed in 2 mL acetonitrile and the mixture was placed in a 10 cm long thick Pyrex glass tube. The sealed tube was heated under autogenous pressure at about 110 °C for 7 days to yield dark red block crystals. The crystals were washed by ethanol, dried, and stored under vacuum (35% yield based on Cd(SPh)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>). Elemental analysis: C<ce:inf loc="post">258</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">214</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>RuCd<ce:inf loc="post">32</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>Se<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf> (9420.49): calcd: C 32.89, H 2.29, N 0.89%; found: C 33.21, H 2.48, N 1.03%. Selected IR data (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3446(m), 3130(w), 1638(m), 1574(m), 1472(s), 1433(m), 1384(m), 1114(w), 1080(m), 1020(w), 741(vs), 689(vs).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis
C2-CdSSeRuBpy (1)
[Ru(Bpy)3][Cd32Se14(SPh)38]. The precursor Cd(SPh)2 (3.0 mg, 0.010 mmol), selenourea (1.0 mg, 0.008 mmol), and Ru(Bpy)3Br2 (1.0 mg, 0.0013 mmol) were mixed in 2 mL acetonitrile and the mixture was placed in a 10 cm long thick Pyrex glass tube. The sealed tube was heated under autogenous pressure at about 110 °C for 7 days to yield dark red block crystals. The crystals were washed by ethanol, dried, and stored under vacuum (35% yield based on Cd(SPh)2). Elemental analysis: C258H214N6RuCd32S38Se14 (9420.49): calcd: C 32.89, H 2.29, N 0.89%; found: C 33.21, H 2.48, N 1.03%. Selected IR data (KBr, cm−1): 3446(m), 3130(w), 1638(m), 1574(m), 1472(s), 1433(m), 1384(m), 1114(w), 1080(m), 1020(w), 741(vs), 689(vs).

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sectitle0055">C2-CdSSeRuPhen (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">[Ru(Phen)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>][Cd<ce:inf loc="post">32</ce:inf>Se<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf>(SPh)<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>]. Dark red block crystals of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were obtained by following a similar procedure to those of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, but Ru(Phen)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (1.0 mg, 0.001 mmol) was used instead of Ru(Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (30% yield). Elemental analysis: C<ce:inf loc="post">264</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">214</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>RuCd<ce:inf loc="post">32</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>Se<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf> (9492.55): calcd: C 33.40, H 2.27, N 0.89; found: C 33.86, H 2.55, N 1.14. Selected IR data (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3473(m), 3132(w), 1631(m), 1575(m), 1473(m), 1431(w), 1402(vs), 1118(w), 1079(m), 1021(w), 739(vs), 689(vs), 582(w).</ce:para>

C2-CdSSeRuPhen (2)
[Ru(Phen)3][Cd32Se14(SPh)38]. Dark red block crystals of compound 2 were obtained by following a similar procedure to those of 1, but Ru(Phen)3Br2 (1.0 mg, 0.001 mmol) was used instead of Ru(Bpy)3Br2 (30% yield). Elemental analysis: C264H214N6RuCd32S38Se14 (9492.55): calcd: C 33.40, H 2.27, N 0.89; found: C 33.86, H 2.55, N 1.14. Selected IR data (KBr, cm−1): 3473(m), 3132(w), 1631(m), 1575(m), 1473(m), 1431(w), 1402(vs), 1118(w), 1079(m), 1021(w), 739(vs), 689(vs), 582(w).

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sectitle0060">C2-CdSSRuBpy (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">[Ru(Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>][Cd<ce:inf loc="post">32</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf>(SPh)<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>]. elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sectitle0080">X-ray crystallography</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0075" view="all">The X-ray crystallographic data of the compounds were carried out on Rigaku Mercury (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), on Agilent (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>) and on Bruker APEX-II CCD (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>) diffractometers with graphite monochromated Mo Kα (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic> = 0.71075 Å) radiation. The structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97  and the refinements against all reflections of the compounds were performed using SHELXL-97 . Crystal data of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, and <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> are available and have been deposited to the CCDC data center, though the cations and solvents of these compounds were not all located because of the disorder problems. The data of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, and <ce:bold>6</ce:bold> are still not satisfying due to their large volumes and disorder. Nevertheless, the data as supporting materials of the compounds are sufficient. Relevant crystal data, collection parameters, and refinement results can be found in . Crystallographic data CCDC 945214–945216 contain the crystallographic data of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, and <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre. The others can be found in .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography
The X-ray crystallographic data of the compounds were carried out on Rigaku Mercury (1), on Agilent (2, 3, 4 and 6) and on Bruker APEX-II CCD (5) diffractometers with graphite monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71075 Å) radiation. The structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97  and the refinements against all reflections of the compounds were performed using SHELXL-97 . Crystal data of 1, 4, and 5 are available and have been deposited to the CCDC data center, though the cations and solvents of these compounds were not all located because of the disorder problems. The data of 2, 3, and 6 are still not satisfying due to their large volumes and disorder. Nevertheless, the data as supporting materials of the compounds are sufficient. Relevant crystal data, collection parameters, and refinement results can be found in . Crystallographic data CCDC 945214–945216 contain the crystallographic data of compounds 1, 4, and 5 for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre. The others can be found in .

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sectitle0085">Electrode preparation and electrochemical measurement</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0080" view="all">All the solvents used in electrochemical measurements were dried by a standard method and distilled before use, or the chromatographically pure reagent. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) experiments were performed on a CHI650 electrochemistry workstation, using a three-electrode system with a Pt plate working electrode, a Pt wire auxiliary electrode and a saturated calomel electrode (SCE) as reference electrode (in CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN with 0.1 mol L<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> Bu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>NClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>). The photocurrent experiments were performed using a quartz cell equipped with the sample coated ITO glass working electrode, a Pt plate auxiliary electrode and a SCE reference electrode, An aqueous solution of Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (100 mL, 0.1 mol L<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) was used as the medium in a quartz cell. The photoelectrodes of the compounds were prepared by powder coating method. As a typical procedure, the crystals of compounds (0.005 mmol) were ground and pressed uniformly on an ITO glass (100 Ω/□) with 0.785 cm<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> effective area (Ø 1.0 cm). A 150 W high pressure xenon lamp, positioned 15 cm away the surface of the ITO electrode, was employed as a light source. The lamp was kept on continuously, and a manual shutter was used to block exposure of the electrode to the light. The electrode was typically irradiated over 0−400 s with interval 20 s. The applied voltage is 0.0 V for photocurrent measurements. Band-pass filters (380, 400, and 420 nm) were used to cut part or all of the UV light for the study of the effect of wavelength.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Electrode preparation and electrochemical measurement
All the solvents used in electrochemical measurements were dried by a standard method and distilled before use, or the chromatographically pure reagent. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) experiments were performed on a CHI650 electrochemistry workstation, using a three-electrode system with a Pt plate working electrode, a Pt wire auxiliary electrode and a saturated calomel electrode (SCE) as reference electrode (in CH3CN with 0.1 mol L−1 Bu4NClO4). The photocurrent experiments were performed using a quartz cell equipped with the sample coated ITO glass working electrode, a Pt plate auxiliary electrode and a SCE reference electrode, An aqueous solution of Na2SO3 (100 mL, 0.1 mol L−1) was used as the medium in a quartz cell. The photoelectrodes of the compounds were prepared by powder coating method. As a typical procedure, the crystals of compounds (0.005 mmol) were ground and pressed uniformly on an ITO glass (100 Ω/□) with 0.785 cm2 effective area (Ø 1.0 cm). A 150 W high pressure xenon lamp, positioned 15 cm away the surface of the ITO electrode, was employed as a light source. The lamp was kept on continuously, and a manual shutter was used to block exposure of the electrode to the light. The electrode was typically irradiated over 0−400 s with interval 20 s. The applied voltage is 0.0 V for photocurrent measurements. Band-pass filters (380, 400, and 420 nm) were used to cut part or all of the UV light for the study of the effect of wavelength.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sectitle0090">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sectitle0095">Synthesis and characterization</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">All materials reported here were synthesized under solvothermal conditions from the Cd(SPh)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and [Ru(Phen/Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]Br<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. The S(-II) and Se(-II) sources were thiourea and selenourea, respectively. The reaction temperatures and solvents for the synthesis of C2 clusters were different from those for the synthesis of C1 clusters. In general, high condensed phase is obtained at high temperature and high volume ratio of the acetonitrile/H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (modifying the solubility of the clusters). To be specific, the C1 cluster was obtained from the mixed solvent of acetonitrile/H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (3:1 in volume) at 85 °C, while pure acetonitrile and 110 °C were suitable for the growth of C2 crystals. The optimized conditions of crystallization of these compounds are described in experimental section. The anion structures of all the six compounds were accurately characterized by X-ray single crystal diffraction. Because there are too many heavy atoms in the large clusters (the largest volume of the cell is about 130 thousands) and the serious disorder of the organic moieties, the cations are not completely solved. The [Ru(Phen/bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cations or Ru<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> (fragment) are found in all the structures of the compounds. The cations have been further characterized by spectra (460 nm MLCT band of [Ru(Phen/Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cation) and electrospray mass spectrum analysis (<ce:italic>m</ce:italic>/<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>: 321.25, ).  shows the TEM images of the aggregated nanoclusters. The XRD patterns of the microcrystal bulk samples along with those simulated from the data of single-crystal analysis are give in .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion
Synthesis and characterization
All materials reported here were synthesized under solvothermal conditions from the Cd(SPh)2 and [Ru(Phen/Bpy)3]Br2. The S(-II) and Se(-II) sources were thiourea and selenourea, respectively. The reaction temperatures and solvents for the synthesis of C2 clusters were different from those for the synthesis of C1 clusters. In general, high condensed phase is obtained at high temperature and high volume ratio of the acetonitrile/H2O (modifying the solubility of the clusters). To be specific, the C1 cluster was obtained from the mixed solvent of acetonitrile/H2O (3:1 in volume) at 85 °C, while pure acetonitrile and 110 °C were suitable for the growth of C2 crystals. The optimized conditions of crystallization of these compounds are described in experimental section. The anion structures of all the six compounds were accurately characterized by X-ray single crystal diffraction. Because there are too many heavy atoms in the large clusters (the largest volume of the cell is about 130 thousands) and the serious disorder of the organic moieties, the cations are not completely solved. The [Ru(Phen/bpy)3]2+ cations or Ru2+ (fragment) are found in all the structures of the compounds. The cations have been further characterized by spectra (460 nm MLCT band of [Ru(Phen/Bpy)3]2+ cation) and electrospray mass spectrum analysis (m/z: 321.25, ).  shows the TEM images of the aggregated nanoclusters. The XRD patterns of the microcrystal bulk samples along with those simulated from the data of single-crystal analysis are give in .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sectitle0100">Description of cluster structures</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0090" view="all">
<ce:bold>Compounds 1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. The crystal of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> belongs to <ce:italic>I</ce:italic>4<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>d</ce:italic> space group with four formulas in one crystal unit. The anion is a 3-D polymeric framework assembled by C2 (Cd<ce:inf loc="post">32</ce:inf>) clusters, in which four CdSe<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> tetrahedra are corner-shared to form a Cd<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Se<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf> cadmium selenide core and the other four selenium ions are located at the center of the triangular surfaces of the supertetrahedron cluster in <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-Se bridge mode (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>). Prior to this work, nearly all C2 clusters were prepared as thio-clusters, except one discrete cluster [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">32</ce:inf>Se<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf>(SePh)<ce:inf loc="post">36</ce:inf>(PPh<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] that was prepared by PhSeSiMe about twenty years ago and the cluster is corner-terminated by PPh<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> molecules . We obtained here the first 3-D <ce:inter-ref id="intref0010" xlink:href="mailto:CdSe@CdS" xlink:type="simple">CdSe@CdS</ce:inter-ref> core–shell clusters. (b) shows the CdSe selenide core and CdSPh shell structure of the C2 clusters.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Description of cluster structures

Compounds 1–3. The crystal of compound 1 belongs to I42
d space group with four formulas in one crystal unit. The anion is a 3-D polymeric framework assembled by C2 (Cd32) clusters, in which four CdSe4 tetrahedra are corner-shared to form a Cd4Se10 cadmium selenide core and the other four selenium ions are located at the center of the triangular surfaces of the supertetrahedron cluster in μ
3-Se bridge mode (
). Prior to this work, nearly all C2 clusters were prepared as thio-clusters, except one discrete cluster [Cd32Se14(SePh)36(PPh3)4] that was prepared by PhSeSiMe about twenty years ago and the cluster is corner-terminated by PPh3 molecules . We obtained here the first 3-D CdSe@CdS core–shell clusters. (b) shows the CdSe selenide core and CdSPh shell structure of the C2 clusters.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0095" view="all">About thirteen C2 clusters have been reported up to date (.), but only three compounds are 3-D polymeric structure. The counterions of the 3-D compounds are all rigid complex cations of [M(Phen)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> or [M(Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> (M = Fe and Ru) . The others are low dimensional structures. In this work we obtained three new C2 chalcogenido clusters with complex cations of [Ru(Phen)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> or [Ru(Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> and they are all 3-D structures. From these results the templating effects of the [M(Phen/Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cations on the 3-D structure are obvious. The structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is constructed by two 3D inter-penetrated diamond frameworks in different symmetry that is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>. The average corner-to-corner distance of the supertetrahedron is 19.24(2) Å (without considering the thiophenol group), and the center-to-center distance of the cluster is 22.205(3) Å. Therefore, it is a 3-D matrix with homosized nano CdSe@CdS core–shell particles (ac 2.0 nm). The structures of the other two compounds <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are similar to <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, except that the Ru(Phen)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> is replaced by the Ru(Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (<ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/c space group) and the selenium ions are replaced by the sulfur ions in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> (<ce:italic>F</ce:italic>ddd space group), .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
About thirteen C2 clusters have been reported up to date (.), but only three compounds are 3-D polymeric structure. The counterions of the 3-D compounds are all rigid complex cations of [M(Phen)3]2+ or [M(Bpy)3]2+ (M = Fe and Ru) . The others are low dimensional structures. In this work we obtained three new C2 chalcogenido clusters with complex cations of [Ru(Phen)3]2+ or [Ru(Bpy)3]2+ and they are all 3-D structures. From these results the templating effects of the [M(Phen/Bpy)3]2+ cations on the 3-D structure are obvious. The structure of 1 is constructed by two 3D inter-penetrated diamond frameworks in different symmetry that is shown in 
. The average corner-to-corner distance of the supertetrahedron is 19.24(2) Å (without considering the thiophenol group), and the center-to-center distance of the cluster is 22.205(3) Å. Therefore, it is a 3-D matrix with homosized nano CdSe@CdS core–shell particles (ac 2.0 nm). The structures of the other two compounds 2 and 3 are similar to 1, except that the Ru(Phen)3 is replaced by the Ru(Bpy)3 in 2 (C2/c space group) and the selenium ions are replaced by the sulfur ions in 3 (Fddd space group), .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0100" view="all">
<ce:bold>Compounds 4</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>. In addition to 3-D C2 clusters, Ru-Phen/Bpy C1 clusters have also been synthesized as discrete molecules <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>. Compounds <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> have the same anion, but the cation are [Ru(Phen)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> and [Ru(Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, respectively. The corners of the C1 clusters of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> are Br<ce:sup loc="post">–</ce:sup> ion coordinated (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>, ), which is from the starting material, while that of <ce:bold>6</ce:bold> is terminated by SPh group (). In these clusters only a simple CdQ<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (<ce:italic>Q</ce:italic> = S or Se) tetrahedral core exists. The coordination of all four corners by –SPh or Br<ce:sup loc="post">–</ce:sup> groups results in discrete clusters that are packed together through noncovalent interactions. The [Ru(Phen)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> or [Ru(Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cations sit in the interspaces of these anions, although only Ru atoms were accurately located. Halide-substituted cluster anions were only found in small T<ce:italic>n</ce:italic> family, such as [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>X<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(SR)<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">4–</ce:sup> (<ce:italic>R</ce:italic> = Ph or MePh, <ce:italic>X</ce:italic> = Cl, Br or I) .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Compounds 4–6. In addition to 3-D C2 clusters, Ru-Phen/Bpy C1 clusters have also been synthesized as discrete molecules 4–6. Compounds 4 and 5 have the same anion, but the cation are [Ru(Phen)3]2+ and [Ru(Bpy)3]2+, respectively. The corners of the C1 clusters of 4 and 5 are Br– ion coordinated (
, ), which is from the starting material, while that of 6 is terminated by SPh group (). In these clusters only a simple CdQ4 (Q = S or Se) tetrahedral core exists. The coordination of all four corners by –SPh or Br– groups results in discrete clusters that are packed together through noncovalent interactions. The [Ru(Phen)3]2+ or [Ru(Bpy)3]2+ cations sit in the interspaces of these anions, although only Ru atoms were accurately located. Halide-substituted cluster anions were only found in small Tn family, such as [Cd10S4X4(SR)12]4– (R = Ph or MePh, X = Cl, Br or I) .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sectitle0105">Description of charge-transfer property</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0105" view="all">Optical diffuse-reflection UV–vis spectra were measured at room temperature using BaSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> as a standard reference. The absorption spectra of the compounds were calculated from the data of diffuse-reflectance and are depicted in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>. Spectra of three C2 compounds are showed in (a). The intense broad bands at about 3.4 eV for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (Se) and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (Se) and 3.8 eV for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> (S) with the onset energy about 2.85 eV for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and 3.20 eV for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are assigned to the cluster-centered excitation, which indicates that the selenide has the narrower energy gap than that of the sulfide. The band at about 2.75 eV is assigned to the metal-to-ligand charge-transfer (MLCT) absorption of the [Ru(Phen/Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cations , which is also the evidence of the presence of these cations in the compounds. The onset energy of the MLCT is about 2.1 eV, which extends the photo absorption to the visible range that significantly narrows the energy gaps of the materials. Based on the results of our previous studies, the shoulder peaks in above 2.9 eV are assigned to charge-transfer bands from cluster anion to [Ru(Phen/Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cation (ACCT) , which overlapped with the MLCT band. (b) shows the spectra difference of the C1 and C2 compounds with the same [Ru(Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cations. Comparing to C2 cluster, the onset energy 3.10 eV for C1 cluster <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> shifts to the blue side due to the decreased size of the cluster.</ce:para>

Description of charge-transfer property
Optical diffuse-reflection UV–vis spectra were measured at room temperature using BaSO4 as a standard reference. The absorption spectra of the compounds were calculated from the data of diffuse-reflectance and are depicted in 
. Spectra of three C2 compounds are showed in (a). The intense broad bands at about 3.4 eV for 1 (Se) and 2 (Se) and 3.8 eV for 3 (S) with the onset energy about 2.85 eV for 1, 2 and 3.20 eV for 3 are assigned to the cluster-centered excitation, which indicates that the selenide has the narrower energy gap than that of the sulfide. The band at about 2.75 eV is assigned to the metal-to-ligand charge-transfer (MLCT) absorption of the [Ru(Phen/Bpy)3]2+ cations , which is also the evidence of the presence of these cations in the compounds. The onset energy of the MLCT is about 2.1 eV, which extends the photo absorption to the visible range that significantly narrows the energy gaps of the materials. Based on the results of our previous studies, the shoulder peaks in above 2.9 eV are assigned to charge-transfer bands from cluster anion to [Ru(Phen/Bpy)3]2+ cation (ACCT) , which overlapped with the MLCT band. (b) shows the spectra difference of the C1 and C2 compounds with the same [Ru(Bpy)3]2+ cations. Comparing to C2 cluster, the onset energy 3.10 eV for C1 cluster 4 shifts to the blue side due to the decreased size of the cluster.

<ce:inf loc="post">1/2</ce:inf>, vs. SCE, oxidation onset potential 1.15 V), while that of compound <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> is observed at about 1.25 V (<ce:italic>E</ce:italic>

The negative shift of the Ru(III)/Ru(II) redox potential is due to the charge transfer from the cadmium chalcogenido cluster anion to the [Ru(Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cation, considering also the charge-transfer band appeared in spectra. 1/2, vs. SCE, oxidation onset potential 1.15 V), while that of compound 4 is observed at about 1.25 V (E

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sectitle0110">Photocurrent responses</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0115" view="all">The CdQ materials are usually photoelectric active and have been interesting until now for their application in photoelectronic materials, but such property has been seldom studied for the cadmium chalcogenido clusters with charge transfer property based on our knowledge. To reveal the photoelectric activity of the charge transfer compounds, a three electrodes photoelectrochemical cell was constructed (a more detailed description is given in the experimental section). Linear sweep voltammograms were recorded both in the dark and light irradiation to profile the <ce:italic>I</ce:italic>−<ce:italic>V</ce:italic> relationship (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig5"></ce:float-anchor>). The current intensity is related to the applied potential and the wavelength of the light. The electrochemical system displays a zero current platform at about −0.66 V vs. SCE (open circuit potential). The onset potentials of the dark current are at −0.10 V and −1.24 V for anodic and cathodic currents, respectively. Photoinduced anodic current enhancement is clearly observed for the electrochemical system. Photo-enhanced current at applied potential 0.0 V vs. SCE is found about 19.5 μA (no filter applied and the datum deducted from the line in dark). The observable photocurrent responses extend to visible range (>420 nm), while the current intensity (absolute value) decreases quickly when the cut wavelength increases.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0120" view="all">

<ce:float-anchor refid="fig6"></ce:float-anchor> shows the photocurrent responses as the excitation light was turned on and off. A sharp photocurrent was generated when the cluster/ITO electrode was subjected to excitation with UV and visible light. The irradiation process was repeated 20 times over 400 s, and the UV light was cut at 380 nm or 400 nm. The reproducible photocurrent responses without noticeable decrease in their relative intensities, despite of the dissimilar base curves, demonstrate the repeatabilities of the photoelectrode responses and hence the mechanical and photophysical stabilities of the electrodes. It should be noted that the current intensity is related to the wavelength of the light and the type of the clusters. The results are summarized as following. (1) The current intensity using a 380 nm UV filter (, the left) is larger than that using a 400 nm UV filter (, the right), about 1.7 times. (2) The current intensities of the 3-D C2 clusters are larger than those of the discrete C1 clusters, comparing (a) and (b) with (e) and (f), (c) and (d) with (g) and (h) in , about 2 times. (3) The current intensities of the selenide clusters are larger than those of the sulfide clusters, comparing (a) and (b) with (c) and (d), (e) and (f) with (g) and (h) in , about 8–10 times. (4) Dark current was clearly found for both the C1 and C2 selenide clusters ((a), (b), (e) and (f), shown in red lines), and for this reason the base lines of their photocurrent drop down in whole or in first part of the experiment range. The different intensities of sulfide clusters and selenide clusters clearly indicate the important roles of the elements in CdQ clusters.</ce:para>

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0125" view="all">

<ce:float-anchor refid="fig7"></ce:float-anchor> shows the photocurrent intensities of the C1 clusters with [Ru(Phen)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cation and the C1 clusters with quaternary ammonium cation (cut at 400 nm). Comparing the RuPhen sensitized CdQ cluster, the current of C1 clusters with quaternary ammonium is very weak. A RuPhen complex only cell is also not a good photoelectron conversion system (). 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig8"></ce:float-anchor> represents the schematic drawing of the photoconductive system and the electron transfer mechanism. The energy gaps of the anion cluster and Ru-Bpy are obtained from the onset energies of the UV–vis spectra ((b)) and their HOMO or LUMO energies are calculated from the onset potentials of the redox peaks in CV results ((c) and ) . These energies are reasonable by comparing with the reported data of the similar materials . Upon light irradiation, the CdS/Se clusters (UV) and Ru-Phen/Bpy complex dyes (UV–Vis) are excited, and under visible light, only the Ru-Phen/Bpy complex is excited. The UV irradiation could induce the electron–hole separation of CdQ cluster, but it is quickly annihilated  and therefore no good photocurrent response for clusters with quaternary ammonium. In the presence of Ru-Phen/Bpy complexes, the electrons transfer from LUMO of the Ru-Phen/Bpy to CB band of the cluster and then inject into the ITO electrode . The ground state of Ru-Phen/Bpy complex dye is recovered by obtaining electron from SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ion. Thus, a steady photocurrent can be observed for the photoelectrochemical system.</ce:para>

These energies are reasonable by comparing with the reported data of the similar materials . In the presence of Ru-Phen/Bpy complexes, the electrons transfer from LUMO of the Ru-Phen/Bpy to CB band of the cluster and then inject into the ITO electrode . The ground state of Ru-Phen/Bpy complex dye is recovered by obtaining electron from SO3
2− ion. Thus, a steady photocurrent can be observed for the photoelectrochemical system.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sectitle0115">Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0130" view="all">Crystals of six large cadmium chalcogenido C2 (Cd<ce:inf loc="post">32</ce:inf>, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) and C1 (Cd<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>) CdQ (<ce:italic>Q</ce:italic> = S, Se) clusters with [Ru(Phen/Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> dyes were prepared under solvothermal conditions, using the thiourea and selenourea as S(-II) and Se(-II) sources. All the C2 compounds are 3-D polymeric structures assembled by nanoclusters (Cd<ce:inf loc="post">32</ce:inf> cluster, ac 2.0 nm), while the C1 compounds are discrete Cd<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf> clusters. Compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, and <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> are CdSe@CdS core–shell clusters. Cation–anion charge-transfer properties of these compounds are demonstrated by spectra and cyclic voltammetry measurements. The conclusions of photocurrent study of these clusters on ITO electrodes are as following: the current intensities of the [Ru(Phen/Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> functionalized C<ce:italic>n</ce:italic> clusters are greatly increased in comparison with those of the C<ce:italic>n</ce:italic> clusters with quaternary ammonium cation; the selenide cluster system is more effective than the sulfide cluster system in photocurrent conversion; the current intensities of the 3-D C2 clusters are larger than those of the 0-D C1 clusters. The charge-transfer, electron transfer and their cooperation are important properties of the cation–anion compounds.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions
Crystals of six large cadmium chalcogenido C2 (Cd32, 1–3) and C1 (Cd17, 4–6) CdQ (Q = S, Se) clusters with [Ru(Phen/Bpy)3]2+ dyes were prepared under solvothermal conditions, using the thiourea and selenourea as S(-II) and Se(-II) sources. All the C2 compounds are 3-D polymeric structures assembled by nanoclusters (Cd32 cluster, ac 2.0 nm), while the C1 compounds are discrete Cd17 clusters. Compounds 1, 2, 4, and 5 are CdSe@CdS core–shell clusters. Cation–anion charge-transfer properties of these compounds are demonstrated by spectra and cyclic voltammetry measurements. The conclusions of photocurrent study of these clusters on ITO electrodes are as following: the current intensities of the [Ru(Phen/Bpy)3]2+ functionalized Cn clusters are greatly increased in comparison with those of the Cn clusters with quaternary ammonium cation; the selenide cluster system is more effective than the sulfide cluster system in photocurrent conversion; the current intensities of the 3-D C2 clusters are larger than those of the 0-D C1 clusters. The charge-transfer, electron transfer and their cooperation are important properties of the cation–anion compounds.
